SleepHealthFramework.Purpose: Sleep optimization for VCI prevention and cognitive health maintenance
SleepHealthFramework.ResearchBasis: Mohammed et al., 2025 - ReCOGnAIze study context; broader sleep neuroscience literature
SleepHealthFramework.CriticalConnection: Sleep quality directly associated with white matter disease progression in cerebrovascular disease

SleepDuration.Age65Plus: Maintain consistent 7-8 hours despite common age-related changes
SleepDuration.CognitiveBenefit: Adequate sleep consolidates memory and clears cerebral metabolic waste (glymphatic function)
SleepDuration.VCIContext: Poor sleep quality linked to increased white matter hyperintensity burden

NREM3.Duration: 15-30 minutes early in night, minimal later
NREM3.Function: Deep sleep for physical restoration and immune function

REM.Function: Emotional regulation, memory consolidation, executive function support

SleepArchitecture.VCIOptimization: Each stage critical for processing speed and executive function maintenance

BedtimeConsistency.Importance: Circadian rhythm synchronization crucial for cognitive function
BedtimeConsistency.Recommendation: Same bedtime and wake time ±30 min daily (including weekends)
BedtimeConsistency.VCIBenefit: Consistent sleep schedule reduces vascular inflammation markers

Temperature.Rationale: Core body temperature drops during sleep; external cold facilitates this

Darkness.Mechanism: Melatonin suppression by light impairs sleep initiation
Darkness.Recommendation: Use blackout curtains, eye mask if needed

Noise.Disruption: Even quiet noise can fragment sleep architecture
Noise.Solution: White noise machine, earplugs, or address noise sources

Humidity.Issue: Dry air irritates airways; excessive humidity promotes allergens

BlueLight.Solution: Blue light filters, or non-negotiable screen-free time before bed

ScreenExposure.MentalStimulation: Evening screens keep brain engaged when wind-down needed

Step1.Action: Dim lights in home to 30% brightness
Step1.Rationale: Signals circadian system of approaching sleep

Step2.Action: Complete last meal or snack (if hungry)
Step2.Guideline: Light snack if needed, avoid heavy meals

Step4.Benefit: Post-bath temperature drop signals sleep onset

Step7.Optional: Journaling, gratitude practice, or gentle stretching

CaffeineMitigation.Metabolism: Half-life ~5 hours; 6 hours after consumption, 25% remains in system
CaffeineMitigation.LastIntakeTiming: No caffeine after 2 PM (to allow clearance by bedtime)
CaffeineMitigation.VCIConsideration: Caffeine-induced sleep fragmentation worsens vascular disease outcomes

Mechanisms: Suppresses REM sleep (70% reduction in early night)
Reduces overall sleep quality despite potentially longer duration
AlcoholAndSleep.HealthData: Even moderate drinking (1-2 drinks) impairs sleep quality
AlcoholAndSleep.VCIRelevance: Poor sleep accelerates white matter disease progression

ExerciseAndSleep.BenefitSummary: Regular exercise significantly improves sleep quality and reduces insomnia
ExerciseAndSleep.TimingConsideration: Exercise too close to bedtime may be stimulating
ExerciseAndSleep.Guideline: Vigorous exercise completed ≥3 hours before bedtime
ExerciseAndSleep.OptimalTiming: Morning or early afternoon aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity)

NappingGuidance.Strategic: Power naps (20 minutes) can boost afternoon alertness
NappingGuidance.Caution: Longer naps (>30 minutes) can cause sleep inertia and worsen nighttime sleep
NappingGuidance.Timing: No later than 3 PM (naps after affect nighttime sleep)
NappingGuidance.VCIContext: Daytime sleepiness may indicate inadequate nighttime sleep or early cognitive decline

SleepRestriction.Method: Limit time in bed to actual sleep time
SleepRestriction.Gradual: Increase by 15 minutes weekly as sleep consolidates

StimulusControl: Use bed only for sleep (and intimacy)
CognitiveRestructuring: Challenge catastrophic thoughts about sleep loss

MelatoninConsiderations.NaturalProduction: Declines with age; accelerated in certain neurological conditions

SupplementGuidance.Duration: Consider cycles (2-3 months on, 1 month off) to prevent tolerance

MelatoninConsiderations.VCIContext: Melatonin has neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory properties
MelatoninConsiderations.Effectiveness: More effective for circadian rhythm disorders than primary insomnia
MelatoninConsiderations.ClinicalNote: Discuss with healthcare provider given vascular disease

SleepApnea.VCIRelevance: Sleep apnea is independent vascular risk factor; worsens VCI progression

Signs: Irresistible urge to move legs in evening

NocturiaExcess.VCIRelevance: May indicate vascular dysfunction or medication side effect

Normal60Plus: Increased sleep latency (time to fall asleep)
AgeRelatedSleepChanges.CriticalPoint: These changes are normal but quality maintenance is possible with intervention

Metrics: Number and duration of nighttime awakenings

WearableDevices.Caution: Moderate accuracy; useful for trends but not clinical diagnosis

Phase4.Focus: Refine based on sleep diary data

CognitiveBenefitTimeline.Week1_2: Improved daytime alertness, easier morning waking
CognitiveBenefitTimeline.Month2: Improved memory consolidation, better reaction time
CognitiveBenefitTimeline.Month3: Noticeable cognitive enhancement, reduced processing delays
